qas.question: What view became popular of the British people in WWII?
When did this popular view come to be?

answers.text: in the 1980s and 1990s, especially after the publication of Angus Calder's book The Myth of the Blitz (1991).

qas.question: Political factions in Britain supported what view of Britains in WWII?

answers.text: aggressive British patriotism successfully defending democracy.

qas.question: What was the Historians' critical response to this view?

answers.text: over-emphasised claims of righteous nationalism and national unity.

qas.question: What did Calder try to expose in his book?

answers.text: some of the counter-evidence of anti-social and divisive behaviours

context: A converse popular image arose of British people in the Second World War: a collection of <a0_0>people locked in national solidarity.<a0_0/> This image entered the historiography of the Second World War <a1_0>in the 1980s and 1990s, especially after the publication of Angus Calder's book The Myth of the Blitz (1991).<a1_0/> It was evoked by both the right and left political factions in Britain during the Falklands War when it was embedded in a nostalgic narrative in which the Second World War represented <a2_0>aggressive British patriotism successfully defending democracy.<a2_0/> This imagery of people in the Blitz was and is powerfully portrayed in film, radio, newspapers and magazines. At the time it was a useful propaganda tool for home and foreign consumption. Historians' critical response to this construction focused on what were seen as <a3_0>over-emphasised claims of righteous nationalism and national unity.<a3_0/> In the Myth of the Blitz, Calder exposed <a4_0>some of the counter-evidence of anti-social and divisive behaviours<a4_0/>. What he saw as the myth—serene national unity—became "historical truth". In particular, class division was most evident.
